rows.VSL SCRIPT ARCHITECTURE: The anatomy of a converting video sales letter

rows.col_4: Pattern interrupt, bold claim, or curiosity gap. Must earn the next 5 seconds.
rows.col_5: Hook rate >25% in Meta Ads Manager

rows.col_4: Describe the problem they live with. Be specific. Use their language.
What they've tried that didn't work. Why those solutions fail.
rows.col_5: Audience nods — "that's exactly what happened to me"

rows.col_4: There IS a solution. Transition from problem world to solution world.
The unique mechanism behind the product. Not features — the reason it works differently.
rows.col_5: Credibility signal — viewer believes the science/logic

rows.col_4: Introduce the product. What it is, what it does, what it contains.
rows.col_5: Clear and simple — viewer can explain product to a friend

rows.col_4: Testimonials, results, numbers. Real people, real outcomes.
rows.col_5: At least 3 proof points from different angles

rows.col_4: What they get. Stack value higher than price. Bonuses if applicable.
Compare to alternatives, daily cost, cost of NOT solving the problem.
rows.col_5: Price feels like a no-brainer given the stack

rows.col_4: Guarantee, refund policy, free trial. Take the risk off them.
rows.col_5: Viewer has zero reason NOT to try

rows.col_4: Clear, specific, urgent. One action. Click, buy, sign up.
rows.col_5: CTA click rate >3% of viewers who reach this point

rows.col_4: Why now, not later. Scarcity, time limit, price increase, limited supply.
rows.col_5: Conversion happens same session, not bookmarked

rows.VSL SCRIPT ARCHITECTURE: Never test one VSL. Always produce 2-3 variants that differ on ONE variable:
Variant A vs B: Different HOOK (same body, same offer)
→ Tests which angle resonates. Most common first test.
Variant A vs C: Different MECHANISM (same hook, same offer)
→ Tests which explanation converts. Run after hook is validated.
Winner vs D: Different OFFER (same hook, same mechanism)
→ Tests which deal structure converts. Run after mechanism is validated.
This is sequential isolation. Change one variable, measure, lock the winner, move to next.
